For the next meeting we will take up Francis Bacon's The New Organon (Publisher: Cambridge University Press; New Ed edition (December 12, 2002); ISBN: 0521564832). We, the participants of the last meeting, preferred to meet on the 2nd and the 4th Thursdays of the month as opposed to the 1st and the 3rd as we have been doing until now. We will try that shift that's why the next meeting is on the 22nd and not on the 15th. The suggested readings form The New Organon are the author's Preface and Book One. As always one can find interesting reading on the internet:
The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy: http://www.utm.edu/re...
Philosophy Pages: http://www.philosophy...
Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy: http://plato.stanford...
The Catholic Encyclopedia: http://www.newadvent....

See you soon!

Couple of questions that may help our discussion about Bacon and The New Organon on Thursday:
1. Why, for Bacon, is fundamental philosophy so essential to charity?
2. Bacon talks about two kinds of experiments (may not be in the text assigned for Thursday): experimenta lucifera and experimenta fructifera. What are these experiments?
3. What is the "Table of Discovery"?
